div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

div.head: Staff Ride
div.p: Major General Bullock, C.B. has gone to Ismailis, accompanied by 14 officers, on a Staff ride.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Today's bulletin records three fresh cases and a death at Ghirgeh, and two cases and a death at Nag Hamadi.

div.head: L'Epargne Immobillere.
div.p: The offices of the Energne Immobiliere, Limited, in Cairo, are sitnated at 24, Sharia El Maghraby, Immeuble Alti Bey, above the offices of the Austrian Lloyd.

div.head: Child Burned to Death.
div.p: While a native child of two years was playing yesterday near a stove in his father's house in the Labbane quarter, his clothes caught fire andd he was burned to death.

div.head: Mascagni to Visit Egypt.
div.p: Mascagni, the world famous author of Cavalleria Rusticana" is coming to Cairo in February and will personally conduct an orchestra at the Abbas Theatre.

div.head: Murder at Damanhour.
div.p: A native woman was found dead in her house at Damanhour yesterday. The postmortem examination showed that she had met her death by foul means, and must have been dead for a week.

div.head: Cairo Carrison.
div.p: Colonel R.C.C. Cox, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, has assumed command of the British Garrison of Cairo, and will continue in command during the absence on duty of the General Officer Commanding.

div.head: Cairo Property Deal.
div.p: The building opposits the Credit Foncier Egyptien, known as M. Veyerle's property in Cairo, has changed hands within the last few days at just under 60 per miere. The buyers are a group of Alexandria and Cairo capitalists.

div.head: Shepheard's.
div.p: No one should miss hearing the new Tzigane Band which has arrived and is playing, under the direction of Maestro Fusco, during the afternoon at Shepheard's. From the 10th inst. the band will perform at Ghezireh Palace on the terrace for afternoon teas.

div.head: Dean Butcher Testimonial.
div.p: We are asked to state that subscriptions to the "Dean Butcher Testimonial Fund" may be paid to that account at the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo and Alexandria, or be sent to Mr. H.H. Du Boulay, the Egyptian Salt and Soda Co., Limited, Boulac, Cairo.

div.head: Wrestling at the Alhambra.
div.p: With regard to the challenge published yesterday, Carl Cylis, the "English" champion, has been selected by Angelo Bazzarini, champion of Alexandria, and the pair will meet this evening at 10.30, when an interesting c t should be witnessed. Other bouts will be place as usual. Space forbid our giving the results of last night's encounters.

div.head: Signs of the Times.
div.p: Among the signs of the coming season at Cairo is the re-opening for the winter of the fashionable establishments in the Ismailia quarter. The well-known Parisian jeweller of the Rue de la Paix, M. Coven-Lacloche, has just opened his premises in Sharia el Manakh, where is to be seen a magnificent assortment of all the latest designs in artistic jewellery.

div.head: Cook's Nile Services.
div.p: The following is a list of passengers by the P.S. Rameses, which is leaving Cairo today for the Nile trip: -- Miss M. L. and Miss J, F. Crellio, Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton, Mr. and Mrs. Nossaert Van Damme, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Round, Mrs. A.P. Westcott, Miss Annie Clark, Mr. E.R. Brahde Smith, Mrs. Gyda Evindvik, Mr. A.L. Sellon, Miss Ella Upjohn, Mr. and Mrs. J.H. Merse.

div.head: Cairo Sessions.
div.p: The Cairo autumn sessions of H.M.'s Supreme Consular Court for the Dominions of the Sublime Ottoman Porte open there today, Judge Cator having arrived in Cairo last night. The first case on the list is that of Spiro Ellul, who is charged with stabbing. On Thursday the most important case of the sessions comes on for hearing, that of coining counterfeit money. The prisoners in this case are Pietro Cameo, Francesco Pace, Walter Cesareo, and Guiseppe Borg. Next Monday the trial will take place of Giovanni B. Vassallo, the ex-post office empoloye, charged with embezzlement. Mr. Preston, barrister-at-law, of Alexandris, is the Crown Prosecutor and the prisoners, all natives of Malta in the three cases, will be defeuded by Maltre Dr. Sciortino, L.L. D.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Menepthah sailed from Malta today at noon for Alexandria.
The Moss liner Amasis sailed from yesterday afternoon and is due here on Friday at daybreak.
The Moss liner Seti sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool, via Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, including 5 225 bales of cotton.
The S.S. Scottish Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left London on the 2nd inst., and is due to arrive at Alesandria on or about the 17th inst.

div.head:
"SCENE" IN REICHSTAG.
GERMAN COLONIAL POLICY.
STARTLING ACCUSATIONS.

div.p: Stormy scenes were witnessed during the debate on the colonial policy on Saturday. Herr Bebel declared that the insurrection in Darmaraland had been a gold mine to contractors. He read a letter detailing horrible atrocities amongst the Cameroons, and named the guilty officers. He asserted that only the small thieves had been hanged, the big ones had escaped. The entire colonial administration, he said, ought to be placed in the dock. He accused three members of the raichstag by name with having abused their position as deputies. This caused an uproar. Another Democratic deputy said that they should look at the criminals. Owing to the tumult the sitting was adjourned. (Reuter)

div.head:
MOROCCO CRISIS.
ADIRAL TOUCHARD IN MADRID.

div.p: Admiral Touchard will command the joint Franco-Spanish forces in Moroccan waters. No forces will be landed except in case of pressing need, and then only after consultation with the Foreign Ministers. (Reuter)
Admiral Touchard has arrived. The Moret Cabinet has resigned. (Havas)

div.head:
TROUBLE IN PERSIA.
CROWN PRINCE TO ASSUME REGENCY.

div.p: According to a telegram received from Teheran, the Crown Prince has been summoned from Tabriz to assume the Regency.
A sharp discord exists between the Parliament and the Court party. The former is for warding a scheme for the establishment of a national bank and an internal loan. (Reuter)
Lieutenant Collard will be tried to courtmartial to day on the charge of the improper use of an order. It opens up the whole question of the order "on the knee." (Reuter)

During the court-martial of Lietenant Collard a petty officer gave evidence that accused on a certain occasion last year, said to a stoker, "Down on your knee, you dog." the stoker obeyed, but rose again and was ordered to the guard room. The matter was afterwards hushed up. Other seamen corroborated this statment but differed in the details. (Reuter)

The laundry women who have been supplanted by Chinamen besieged the new comers in the Chinese Club yesterday. They attempted to storm the premises, but were prevented by a barricade. They then stoned the windows. (R)
The reported illness of Menelik is unfounded. (Reuter)
Hazim Bey, Vali of Monastir, has been appointed Vali of Baghdad. (Reuter)

div.head: ANDRASSY AND THE TRIPLICE.
div.p: The Emperors William and Francis-Joseph exchanged- cordial telegrams concerning the unveiling of the statue of Andrassy, whose name is inseparable from the establishment of the Triple Alliance. Havas

div.head: MAPLE AND Co., Ltd.
div.p: (LONDON AND PARIS)
UPHOLSTERERS TO H.M. KING EDWARD VII.

Beg to announce that their representative, Mr. T Oliver, is now staying at the New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria, where he will remain till December 24th, and where he will be pleased to make appointments and to give his advice on all matters concerning Furniture and Decoration.
Mr. Oliver will be in Cairo at Shepheard's Hotel, from December 25th, till the end of January.

div.head:
SIRDAR'S TOUR IN KORDOFAN..
ENTHUSIASTIC RECEPTION.
div.p: Reports just received show that Sir Reginald Wiugate, K.C.B., Governor General of the Sudan, who is at present on a tour of inspection in the White Nile and Kordofan Provinces, is everywhere meeting with an enthusiastic reception from the natives of the various towns and villages en route. At Dueim, which was decorated for the occasion, and at Um Dam and the smaller villages which were passed, his Excellency was greeted by enthusiastic crowds. On every side were evidences of the remarkable development of the country since the Sirdar's last visit to the district in 1901. It was evident that an increase of population alone is needed to enable enormous tracts of the extremely fertile land in these districts to be planted with dura and dukn.

Bara was reached on the 26th, and here his Excellency was met by the officials and Sheikhs ali el Tom (of the Kababish) Abdullah Gadallah (of the Kababish) Abdullah Gadallah (of the Kawahla), Munhal Kheirallah (of the shenabala), the omdeh of the district, and by hundreds of minor sheikhs. After inspecting the towns and barracks, his Excellency held a largely attended reception at the Mamourieh. His Excellency's visit to El Obeid on the 28th was made the occasion of a magnificent demonstration. He was met on his entry to the town by 1,500 horsemen under their sheikhs, while on either flank charged horsemen in robes and coats of mail with spears and ponnauts. The streets, which were thronged by cheering onlookers, were gaily decorated with bunting and flags, and were lined with irregular Arab and Nuba riflemen. Every Arab tribe was represented and it is difficult to estimate the numbers of Nuba and Dinkas present. Amongst other sheikhs present was Hamid Abusakin and his followers.

Subsequently the troops, who were 1,050 strong, consisting of the Camel Corps and detachments from the 8th and 15th Battalions, with guns, paraded before his Excellency. Messengers from Ali Dinar, of Darfur, attended, bringing with them three stallions as presents to the Government.

In the evening the town was brilliantly illuminated and there was a firework display followed by a torchlight "tattoo" and Daluka (native dance) which was attended by the officers, native notables, and European merchants. Throughout the afternoon and evening enthusiastic crowds thronged the streets.

div.head: ANGLICAN CHAPEL FOR PORT SUDAN.
div.p: Archdeacon Gwynne, on Sunday last, consecrated the new Anglican chapel at Port Sudan, and held devine services there for the first time, afterwards leaving for Khartoum.

In my last notes I mentioned that Bimbashi Lord would replace Bimbashi Newcombe as railway agent at Suakin. This arrangement has now been altered, as Mr. Hickley, district engineer Suakin-Atbara line, has arrived here from Gebeit and taken over the duties of agent at Suakin. Bimbashi Newcombe, R.E. has left for Atbara to take over the duties of traffic manager from Kaimakam Sowerby Bey, R.E. Bimbashi Lord will remain as assistant chief engineer of ways and works.

It has been decided to erect a large bridge from the present railway station in Port Sudan town across the narrow neck of the harbour, for trains to run into the town. This bridge has been ordered and the excavations for the masonry work habe been commenced. The railway line from Asortriba to Port Sudan, which ahs been bridged, has now been slightly altered and the bridging by the contractor, Mr. George Urquart, will soon commence. Mr. Urquart is at present in Cairo engaging new hands for the work.

div.head: KEHDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: We publish elsewhere a series of resolutions to be submitted to the shareholders of the Khedivial Mail Line at an "extraordinary" meeting to be held in London on the 14th inst. We understand that these resolutions have to be passed by the shareholders to enable the directors to proceed with the intended emission of additional ordinary shares, which will be offered in the first place to the existing ordinary shareholders, who, we have little doubt, will eagerly avail themselves of the opportunity of increasing their holding.

div.head: HELOUAN (EGYPT) DEVELOPMENT COMPANY.
div.p: We would draw the attention of our readers to the prospectus of this company which is published in another column. The success of this new company is assured owing to the certain development of the town of Helouan, and to the great advantages which the directors have already secured in the acquisition of property on advantageous terms. The promoters are all business men, who are well and favourably known.

div.head: A ROUMOR.
div.p: The "Mokattam" gives currency to a rumour, which lacks confirmation, that Mr. Mitchell Innes, Under Secretary to the Ministry of Fianance, will be appointed Adviser to the Council of Ministers, when he will have an office in the Khedivial Mih.

div.head:
SITUATION IN EGYPT.
MR. COPE WHITEHOUSE AGAIN.
div.p: Under the heading of "The Situation in Egypt," the "Wall Street Journal" (New York) publishes the following letter from Mr. Cope Whitehouse, with the subject of which we deal in our leading article today: --

It is now obvious that the Egyptian financial situation has been hitherto misrepresented and misunderstood. It would appear doubtful wheather, until whithin the last few months outside of a few European banking houses, there was any conception of the liabilities which had been incurred; or appreciation of the dangerous facility with which a large amount of gold; amounting, perhaps, to forty million dollars, might be suddenly transferred from the principal banks to the private revenes, or secret boards of small peasant proprietors in the Delta. An Egyptian cotto crop of about 550,000,000 pounds represents over a hundred million dollars.

After the British occupation, Sir Edgar Vincent, as Financial Adviser, created an Egyptian silver coinage, in order that the seigniorage of this "token money" could be used for current expenditure. The process has continued to the present time. According to Mr. Roussin, there was "a superabundance" of silver coin in December, 1904; yet, during 1904, the Government issued a further amount of $2,625,000, redeemable at par in gold. "Stocks of silver coin accumulated in the hands of bankers and merchants, who found it impossible to dispose of them. The superfluity of gold coin, (estimated at about 60% of the import for that year), found its natural outlet through th emedium of re-export, but that of silver remained as a clog on the internal trade, representing a lock-up of capital attended with loss to those who were unfortunate enough to find themselves its custodians. To remedy this situation and to relieve the community of an unequal burden, there was evidently one measure and one only indicated, to wit, the assumption of the charge by the Government. Arrangements were accordingly made in January, 1905, to receive silver coins against gold at the Government treasuries and at the National Bank of Egypt." No statistics are available to show what is the whole amount of Egyptian silver that has been coined. Although gold is now going to Egypt, with a probable diminution in December and January, yet, in 1905, it was imported into Egypt as late as March and April. A portion of this was re-exported in June and July, leaving, however, $15,000,000 as a permanent loss, for that year only, to the international specie reserves of America and Europe.

The important point made is, how to ascertain what provision has been made by the Financial Adviser to meet the January coupons and other financial obligations of an equally peremptory character. The more the incongruous and contradictory statements, put forth apparently on the highest authority, are examined, the greater the puzz's and the worse the outlook. The interest on the debt is $17,940,555, exclusive of the Turkish tribute, and other similar charges. The Unified, $179,860,000 is, according to M. Delcasse, all held in France. It calls for $11,194,400 annually. Evidently the Bank of France, and not the Bank of England, will be required to earmark so much of its gold reserve as may be required to meet the interest on this part of the Egyptian debt.

The reserve fund, which Lord Cromer reported at $60,440,000 in January, 1906 is in reality only $5,250,000, in depreciated silver money, a poor equivalent with which to meet gold coupons due in Paris and London.

It may be considered as certain that the Bank of England raised its rate as part of a series of operations, by which it is endeavouring to arrange to carry over Egyptian commmitments, until, in April, 1907, a Fractional part of the gold now going to Egypt may be re-exported to Europe. It is equally clear that the Bank of France is now co-operating, and making provision for the movement of the cotton crop as well as for the January dividends on the Unified.

div.head: THE DONGOLA IN COLLISION.
div.p: The Dongola came into collision in the Canal with the R.M.S. Orontes. The latter sustained some damage.

div.head: RESCUE OF A LASCAR.
div.p: The R.M.S. orontes landed at Suez yesterday a Lascar named Youssef Ali who was picked up at sea near Colombo in the following circumstances: -- At 9 p.m. on the 22nd November last, when the Orontes was about a mile outside the breakwater, a human voice was heard, apparently calling for help. The ship's engines were at once stopped and reversed and a boat lowered, and at 9.55 the latter returned with a native in a very exhausted condition. He was immediately attended to by the surgeen, and through an interpreter he stated that he was a native of Sy'hat, aged 20 years, a Mohamedan fireman belonging to the S.S. Chisholm, which left Colombo at 7 p.m. on the 22nd ult. He stated that he fell overboard about that hour just after the vessel left. the man had been in the water for about two hours, and it is remarkable that he was not devoured by sharks.

div.head: DEPARTURE OF ROYAL BERKS.
div.p: The special train conveying the 2nd Battalion Royal Berks. Regiment arrived at Suez Docks early this morning. The S.S. Dongola came out of the Canal at 7 a.m., when the troops were transported to the ship in lighters. The Dongola sailed from Suez bound to Karachi at 4 p.m.

div.head:
ARE EGYPTIANS FANATICS?
MOSLEMS V. COPTS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
Sir, -- In your Monday's issue I noticed a letter written by a "Native of Upper Egypt," which I read with interest, and would like to remark upon.

Your correspondent, if I understand him rightly, begins by asking the question at the head of his letter, and then says that an answer in the negative or affirmative is equally fallacious. This seems rather paradoxical to anyone who is accustomed to receive a plain answer to a plain question.
Personally I believe that all Moslems are at least potential fanatics, and I have lived among them for many years in Morocco, South Arabia, and East Africa.

There seems to me no question about the unrest that obtains at present Egypt. I was here lat in 1897, and on this second visit was astonished at the general attitude of insolence and intolerance adopted towards Europeans by the lower classes of natives in teh streets of Cairo.
Your correspondent goes on to inform us that this feeling of contempt towards Christians is based largely upon the attitude adopted towards Copts in the various schools throughout the country.

He tells us that native Christians are not received with the same enthusiasm as Moslem pupils, and that the Copts have to observe Mohamedan holidays, while the Moslems-- although in a minority-- have the school kept open for them during 'Xmas, etc. He moreover compmlains that Moslems are invariably preferred to native Christians, when applying for Government billets, and adds a somewhat vagne warning, that unless these things are altered, our British administration is likely to meet with trouble. I sympathize with your correspondent. It does seem hard to have to take a back seat, after having enjoyed the plums of Government service for many years.

I belong to the Church of England and have for the last twelve years worked and travelled among the up country tribes of South Arabia and Somaliland; engaged on scientific research, or work in connection with the Intelligence Department. I have seen the fighting Arab-- both desert horsement and mountaineer-- in his own home, and have learnt to appreciate his good qualities, which are engendered and fostered by the religion that he adheres to. I admit that he may be justly charged with a blood-thirsty and vindictive spirit and sometimes treachery --and always sensuality; but he can also lay claim to sterling courage, endurance, patriotism, and frugality. His hospitality is proverbial and his marvellous gifts of poetry and imagery must be experienced to be properly appreciated.

The Moslem is, however, by nature a poor scholar. His restless temperament and the narrow groove in which Islamic education runs, are no doubt, factors against him. The Copts and many other intellectual races have taken advantage of this for centuries races have taken advantage of this for centuries, and now Islam is forging ahead in this respect, it behoves your correspondent and his co-religionists to make a strenuous effort to again out strip the Moslem in education as they used to do, not forgetting to preserve and foster among thier younger generation traditions of integrity and honour, without which no intellectual gifts can ever obtain recognition from those in high places. Surely your correspondent does not really think that the "superiority" (as he terms it) of Christianity required demonstrating by proclamative or secular teaching. If any contempt rests upon Christians it is caused by our own actions, and not by the religion which we adhere to, for Moslems themselves deeply reverance the name of Christ as a Prophet and Teacher, as every student knows, and frequent passages in the Koran speak of a kindly and respectful attitude towards Christians.

Christianity can stand alone, without being bolstered up by Government edicts; in fact, she has never flourished better than in the stress of persecution, as we all know-- and if we Christians want to make our religion respected in an alien country instead of merely displaying a complacent feeling of superiority, we might try what we can do by practising a few of the Christian virtues which we have been taught upon the people around us.

I don't personally think much of the Cairene lowwer-class Moslems, but criticism is out of place, for we must remember that they have been brought more closely into touch with Europeans than perhaps any other of their co-religionists throughout the world. it is a melancholy fact that we do not improve Islamic races, wherever we come in contact with them.

Meanwhile I hope that "A Native of Upper Egypt" will "keep his tail up" and not fall back among the rack; and also bear in mind that in Moslem country, Islamic holidays will naturally receive preference in most schools-- Yours, etc.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive granted an audience yesterday at Abdeen Palace to Sheikh Mohamed Shakir, acting Chancellor of AlAzhar, who presented to his Highnesss the graduates who obtained the ulema certificate from Al Azhar at the last examination.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: As mentioned by us a few days back, Sir John Harrington, K.C.V.O., British Minister at the Court of the Emperor Menelik, is expected in Cairo some time next month. He started from Adis Abeba in October, and as he remains in Egypt for about a week, as the guest of Lord Cromer, Colonel Harrington is not likely to be in England before some time in February. At present he is travelling through the different British Protectorates in Africa. Later on in the spring he will be included in one of the King's house parties at Sandringham, and this will remind him that three years ago, on the King's birthday, he was knighted by his Majesty in the ballroom at Sandringham, Wither he had been commanded to attend.
Mahmoud Pasha Mukhtar, eon of Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha, arrived at Alexandria yesterday on his return from Europe, accompanied by his family.
Mr. Pio Sciortino, British Pro-Consul in Cairo, has returned from leave, and resumed his duties.
Mrs. Carton de Wiart arrived in Cairo yesterday after an absence of eight months.
Mrs. Scott-Peat, widow of Colonel Scott-Peat, late of the Bombay Cavalry, intends coming out to Egypt after Christmas, and will reside at the National Hotel in Cairo for several months.

div.head: RE-OPENING OF THE SAVOY.
div.p: The bright lights streaming over the verandah at the Savoy Hotel last evening were very welcom tokens, telling us that once more the doors were open and another season was at hand. The visitors who have already taken up their quarters there include the Marquis di Pioravanti, Prince F. de Caraman Chimey, Baron de Langadorfl, Lt. Col. J. Parker, Dr. Wm. Armstrong, Mr. Herbert N. Gutmann, Major and Mrs. Wynne, Miss Blyth, Miss Stone, Mr. and Miss Cochrane, Commander Sir Hamilton Fraser Smith, Mrs. Berkeley James, Miss Foster and Miss Wigram. Amongst those who are expected shortly are Mrs. Anderson and her daughters, who were so well known in Cairo two winters ago, and Lady Muriel and Mr. Beckwith, who are returning after a visit to Khartoum.

div.head: THE KING'S OWN SCOTTISH BORDERS.
div.p: THE HISTORY OF A GALANT OLD REGIMENT.

As already announced in the "Gazette," the 1st Battalion King's Own Scottish Borders, under the command of the Lieutenant Colonel D.A. Macfarlane, D.S.O., with Major C.J.A. McArthur second in command, arrived at Alexandria, per the S.S. Dongola, on Saturday, and proceeded to Cairo, where they are now quartered in the Citadel.

The King's Own Scottish Borders had their origin in the stirring days of the Revolution of 1688-89. When the news of the successful landing of William Prince of Orange, at Torbay, and the flight of James from England, reached Scottland, some 6,000 westland Covenauters rose and marched to Elinburgh, and laid siege to the castle in the name of William. Their banners bore a badge the open Bible and the motto, 'For Reformation, according to the word of God." From amongst these worthies the gallent Earl of Leven formed a regiment, under a commission from William, dated march 10th, 1689. Inside the almost incredible time of twenty four hour the regiment was recruited to 800 ran and file, officed, armed, and equipped. After the Castle fell, the "Elinburgh, Regiment," as it was then designated, went with Mackay's army in the operations against the Jacobite Highlanders. At the Battle of Killiecrankie the regiment, along with an English one, now the Somersetshire Light Infantry, "saved the honour of the army," by covering the retreat of the others when the victorious Highlanders swept the field in an all conquering charge. Subseqently the regiment was conceded with the unique priviledge of "beating up for recruits in Edinburgh at any time without asking leave of the Lord Frovost," and it enjoys the same obsolete priviledge to the present day. Its next services were in the Williamite wars in Ireland 1691-92, during which it participated in the sieges of Athlone, Galway, and Limerick, and other Irish garrisons which held out gallantly in a worthless cause. In pursuance of William's policy of crushing the power in France, as soon as Ireland was pacificated, the regiment was sent with others to join the allies in Flanders, At the battle of Steinkirk, where the Williamite troops were defeated by sheer weight of numbers, the Edinburgh Regiment fought so stubbornly that it was almost cut to pieces, along with four other British regiments on which the brunt of the fighting fell."The ground where the conflict raged was piled with corpses, and those who buried the slain remarked that almost all of the wounds had been given in close fighting by the sword or bayonet." No return of teh killed and wounded was made, but in the brigade to our regiment belonged, 102 officers, and 1,114 rank and file alone were killed and wounded. The Edinburgh Regiment was recruited by drafts for the battle of Landen, and here again it was stricken heavily. It was of this action -- sometimes called "Nearwinden," --that Macanley wrote his well known lines: "It is probable at amongst the 120,000 soldiers who were marshalled round Neerwinden under all the banners of Western Europe the two feeblest in body were the hunchbacked dwarf (the Duke of Luxembourg) who urged forward the firey onset of France, and teh asthmatics skeleton (William) who covered the slow retreat of England." Technically, Luxembourg won, but he lost so many men --some 15,000 in action-- that his victory (1) was no advantage to him. Amongst the slaim was the brave Irish soldier. Patrick Sarsfield, Earl of Lucan, and 20,000 corpses -- almost as many as, were killed in the three years' fighting of the late Boer war-- on the field attested to the stubbornness with which 60,000 British and Dutch contested the field against 95,000 French. William, as in all his previous battles, took the risks in action of the common soldiers. Two of his led horses we killed beside him, one bullet passed through his hat, a second pierced his coat, and a third struck his scarf knot and wounded his side. At the seige of Namur the Elinburgh Regiment bore a gallant part, which reminds us that at this time the originals of "Uncle Toby" and "Corporal Trim," immortalised in Sterne's "Tristram Shandy," were serving in the corps. We fear that the godly spirit of 1689 had sadly deteriorated, for the unimpeachable "Uncle toby" has left it on record that "our army swore in Flanders," in a manner leaving nothing to be desired, and speaking from personal knowledge, we regret that in ungnarded moments modern Tommy Atkins is wont to express himself in a sufficiently lurid style to establish a claim to regimental heredity. "Uncle Toby" was Captain Stern, uncle of the author, and "Corporal Trim" was Corporal James Butler. At the storming of Namur, King William directed the attack, and as he saw his victorious redcoats force the breaches he cried to the Elector of Bavaria, "Look, look at my brave English." Brave, ind, they were, for the bones of 2,000 of the Namur's walls. It may be of erest dd that in this campaign, which was nated in 1697, by the peace Byk, Colonel Maxwell, who commanded the regiment adopted the sockated bayonet, and his men were enabled to fire in action with fixed bayonets. During the Jacobite Rebellion of 1715 and the Vigo Bay expedition, 1719, the regiment saw considerable service and it also shared in the defense of Gibraltar in the siege of 1727-28. The long wars of the Spanish succession gave the 25th Regiment, as it had been styled, opportunities of again proving its valour, and at Dettingen, under the eye of King George II., the last British king who risked his life in action, it contributed its share in gaining that victory, although it is not borne of the colours, and at the battle of Fontery, after fighting valiantly for victory, it was one of the last in retreat. From the Continent it was hurriedly recalled as the Highland Jacobites had again risen, and in the campaign of 1745 it was actively employed at Falkirk and Culloden, which last action for ever crushed the hope of the Stuarts. This over, the 25th was sent back to the Continent for the conclusion of the war there, and acquired fresh distinctions at Val, where it captured two French standards.

The outbreak of the Seven Years' War once more found the 25th in the tented field, and one of its first actions in that protracted struggle, and the first on its regimental colours, was the battle of Minden, fought on 1st August, 1759, by 30,000 British and their allies, under Prince Ferdinand of Brunswick, and 69,000 French and Bavarians, under Marshal de Contades. The skillful maneuvring of Prince Ferdinand led Constades to believe that all he had to do was to advance and drive the allies off the field, but at the end of a rapid march, the tables were turned, and the allied forces, although much inferior numerically, having lured the French into an unfavourable position. attacked them on the plain of Minden, which town was in possession of the French. In a morning remarkable for beauty, we are told that the 12th, 23rd, and 37th British regiments, followed by the 20th, 25th, and 51st, under Major General waldegrave and Major General Kingsley, and flanked by two battalions of Hanoveriann Foot Guards and the regiment of Hardenburg, supported by three battalions of Hanoverians and a battalion of Russian Foot Guards, advanced to attack the left wing of the French army, where Marshal de Contades had posted the elite of his calvary, the carabineers and genarmes. The 12th, 23rd, and 37th led the attack in gallant style. As they moved forward the enemy'sartillery opened a tremendous fire, and the French carabineers advanced to charge the British infantry. A volley fro mthe leading regiments smote the charging equadrons ; many men fell; the survivors reined up their horses, wheeled about, and retired, their artillery recommencing its fire as the horsemen cleated the front. The Hanoverian Brigade came up, on the left of the British regiments. Soon another line of French cavaliers, gay in splendid uniforms, and formidable in numbers, came forward, the soldiers shouting and waving their swords: but they were struck in mid onset by a tempest of bullets from the British regiments, brok, and driven back with severe loss. Pressing onward with a conquering violence the British brigades became exposed to the fire of the enemy's musketry; but nothing could sotp them. Elevated by success and confident in their own prowess, they followed up the advantages they had already gained, and drove the French cavalry out of the field. Two brigades of French infantry endeavoured to stem the torrent of battle, but they were broken and dispersed. A body of Saxon troops made a show of coming down on the British regiments, but they were too soon put to flight. The enemy's line gave way, a general confusion among the French regiments followed, and the numerous legions of France were driven from the field, with a loss of 43 pieces of cannon, ten pair of colours, seven standards, and many officers and soldiers. At the succeeding actions of Warbourg, Gumpen, Fellinghausen, and Wilhelmethal the 25th was present, and needless to say acquitted itself gallantly. Whilst at home in 1782 an arrogant Lord Provost of Edinburgh contested the privilege of the 25th to beat up recruits in the city without his permission, and territorial names then coming into fashion, the name of the corps was changed to the 25th "Sussex Regiment," on the application of Lord George Henry Lennox, Mr. P., Colonel of the regiment, who was much angered at the slight put on it. Under this name the 25th took part in the relief of Gibraltar 1782, and the remainder of its defence up till the seige was raised the following year. During the Revolutionary war the 25th saw much service as marines on the flee's of Lord Howe, Lord Hood, and Admiral Hotham, two detachments of the Marlborough and Gibraltar representing it on the "Glorious First of June," 1794. Details left in England were raised to two battalions, which did duty in the West Indies, and the whole corps subsequently was reunited into a single battalion for the expdedition to Holland 1799. At the battle of Egmont-op-Zee, the Grenadier company notably distinguished itself and two years later the regiment was in Abercromby's army which beseiged and captured Alexandria and drove Napoleon's "Invincibles," as they arrogantly styled themselves, rom the "Land of the Pharaohs." A second battalion was formed in the border counties in 1804, but did not see any active service till almost the close of the Peniusular war, when it was represented at Stalaund and Rostock, 1813, and in Holland, 1814-15. when Waterloo was fought and won, it was in garrison at Antwerp. Meanwhile, King George III, by a general order, dated May 7th, 1805 was pleased to direct that the 25th should be known as "25th King's Own Borders," and under that designation the 1st battalion had a varied service from 1807, including teh occupation of Madeira, the capture of Martinique, 1809, its recapture in 1815, and Guadeloupe, the same year. The 2n battalion was disbanded in 1816. Whilst the depot was at Berwick in 1826 the ancient privilege of beating up recruits in the Scottish capital without the leave of Bumbledom was revived and confirmed. From 1842, when it saw some service against the Boers, down till the Afghan war 878-80 it saw no active service, if we except the Fenian fiasco in Canada in 1866. In Afghanistan, it saw a lot of hard service, including the expedition to the Hazara Valley. A 2nd battalion was raised in 1859, and its record of ervices includes the operations on the Sudan frontier, 1889, the Chitral campaign. 1896 and the Tirah expedition of 1898. In 1887 the name of the regiment was altered to its present one, the "King's Own Scottish Borders" and under the territorial scheme of 1881 the depot was permanently loted at Berwick. When Paul Johannes Kruger sent his famous ultimatum to Britain in October, 1889, the 1st Battalion was stationed in the Irish capital. When it came apparent that it was not "a little war," but one of considerable dimensions that the Empire was to engage in, the battalion was sent to Aldershot, where it was rapidly mobilised and despatched to the Cape from Southampton on the 4th January, 1900, as a unit of Chermside's or the 14th Brigade in Tucker's 7th Division. A month later, the battalion, 1,000 strong, under Lieutenant Colonel J.W. Godfray, was in teh thick of the fighting for the relief of Kimberley. It was in the actions leading up to Cronje's surrender at Paardeberg, where it had several casualties, including Captain Pratt, wounded; Poplar Grove, Driefrontein, and Karree Siding. In the latter action, one of the sharpest of the campaign, the brunt of the battle fell on the Borderers and East Lancashires, to whose lot it fell to clear the Boers from a position which was almost impregnable. It was at first thought the Dutchmen had abandoned teh kopjes till a tremendous fire at close quarters showd they had not. Captain Goingaa brave Irish officer, was killed, Lieutenant E.M. young, was mortally wounded, two other officers were wounded, and the regiment lost 20 stout fellows, and 50 were wounded. One Boer shell killed five men. This action cleared this part of the country, so that they did not die in vain. The Borderers were at the crossing of the Vet and Zand Rivers, and participated in teh fighting outside Johannesburg and the march on Pretoria. About this time the Borderers, with the Berkshires, Argyll and Sutherland's, Mahon's and Pilcher's mounted infrantry, with some artillery, including M. Battery R.H.A., were formed into a separate command, under Major General Ian Hamilton, and it is recorded of his "little army," that it put in as much hard work in marching and fighting as any body of troops in the whole campaign, as a glance over Lord Roberts's despatches will show. From that period, the battalion was very actively engaged in the harassing pursuit of the Boer guerillas, and had its full share in the "drives" and "bags" made down to the close of the war, including the actions at Vlakfontein, Zilikats Nek, for detailed description of which want of space prevents us. Suffice to say that during the wearisome war the Borderers fought as valiantly and suffered as uncomplainingly as did their regimental ancestors in the long gone campaigns above referred to. But many a brave lad from teh tweedside, the hills and glens of Dumfries, Selkirk, and Roxburgh, lies under the veldt for the honour of the gallant old 25th. The regimental casualties by battle and disease were 200, and comparitively few of the original rank and file returned home with the colours. The regiment is recruited in the shires above mentioned and these probably produce the best type of Lowland soldier for they are the descendants of the turbulent hard-fighting men of the Border Marches. The colours of the Borderers bear the triple Castle of Edinburgh and the city motto, "Nisi Dominos Frustra," the regimental motto, "In Veritate Religionis Confido," underneath the King's crest, the White Horse of Hanover, and its motto, "Nec Aspera Terrent," in commmemoration of its services against the Jacobites and the following battle honours-- 'Minden," "Egmont-op Zee," "Egypt" (with the Sphinx) "Martinique" "Afghanistan," 1878-79-80," "Chitral," "Tirah," "South Africa, 1900-02," and "Paardeberg."

div.head: UNE CREPULE D'ISLAM
div.p: M. Andre Chevrillon, whose study of our Coronation attracted great and deserved attention in England, in his "un Crepuscule d'Islam" (Paris, Hachette) improves upon his "Terres Motres," or volume on the Holy Land. This time it is a visit to Fez with which the word pictures are concerned. The style of the earlier descriptions here reminds us of Fromentin's two volumes upon Algeria; and the chosen band of readers know this to be the highest praise. In Fromentin perfection of style is attained in passages which contain but little thought; and thought, as contrasted with poetry, is somewhat wanting in Fromentin's African books. M. Chevrillon showed in his English studies the highest powers as a critic and historian; but it is not easy to combine his best work as regards substance with his best in form. When, therefore, he reaches Fez and speculates upon the stagnation of Islam, there are passages in which style degenerates into mannerism, while the thought is at a high level. The detachment from the world of the really religions Mohamedan, as he is found among the Moors of illustraious lineage, has been described by many writers -- never better than by M. Chervillon. The contrast presented within two or three miles of the most venerated mosques by the equally separate, through extraordinarily different Jewish world is put before the reader by M. Chevrillon with the vividness of Mr. Kipling, but with French abherence to literacy tradition. In his account ohis reception by the Jews who are compelled to live in thier separate, walled quarter 'in the shade of Fez," M. Chevrillon reaches the highest point that he has yet attained in philosophic travel, just as in the earliest pages of this volume he reaches his highwater mark of style. Our author is well acquainted with the result of the recent investigation into the ethnography of the Jews. He knows that they are but partly descendedm from the sacred tribes -- that they have incorporated, in teh course of their strange history, Tentons, Slavs, Ugrians, and people of many other races. The traditions of the chosen people, and the circumstances in which they have been compelled to live, have imprinted upon all common characteristics which are powerfully illustrated in this chapter. The Mohamedan world and the Jewish world have both the advantage over us of rejecting the colour test and the colour bar: one of the superioritie whi account for the continued progress of the Mohamedan religion in Africa and in the Malay Archipelago, and for the vitality of the Jews.
FAREWELL FOOTBALL MATCH.
INNISKILLING FUSILIERS
VERSUS
LANCHASHIRE FUSILIERS.
(FROM A CORRESPONDENT.)

The above two well-known rivals met at Ghezireh in a friendly encounter. The Irishmen were bady handicapped owing to several of their players being on the sick list. At the time appointed for starting, only five Lancashire men turned out, but as time wore on they all appeared. The inniskillings were represented as follows: Goal, Howlett; backs, Branagh and Ward; halves, Strain, Williamson, and Smyth; forwards, Kenns, Hutton, Dougan, Hugginson, and Walsh.

There was only a moderate attendance of spectators. The Lancs, having won the toss, Dougan started the ball arolling for the Skinshires. Play went towards teh Lancs' custodian the backs relieving only for a moment however, as Ireland came away again, Hutton sending past. On the kick-off the Lancs' halves made ground. Casey the outside left got hold of the sphere, and ran the entire length of the field, but before he had time to shoot Branagh deprived him of the ball. Midfield play followed, and Dougan got possession of the ball, and gave to Higginson, who, dodging two opponents, gave to Walsh, who sent in a shot which was well saved. The Lancs' keeper was getting plenty to do. Some pretty passing was seen between the Lancs' forwards, and a visit was paid to Howlett, who saved in smart style. The Green and Buff Brigade now got away per Hutton, who gave to Kenna. The latter centered well. Higginson snatching up the pass banged in the first goal for the Inniskillings. On resuming the Inniskillings had play all in their favour. The Lancs' possess a gold team but Casey, their outside left, should pass oftener. Walsh and Higginson were playing a steady game. The new recruit, Kenna, is not bad and he deserves another trial. Nothing of importance occurred up to half time, the score standing:
Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers ... ... 1 good
Lancashire Fusiliers... ... ... ... Nil

The second half was opened by Blank kicking off for the Lancs, who at once made towards Howlett, Wescot sending in a "beauty" which was saved in grand style. Touch was now the order for some time, until Wescot got away and he sent in strongly to goal. The ball struck the inside of the bar and bounded out of Howlett's reach in the net, making the scores equal. The pace after this was hot. The Inniskillings advanced per Dougan, who centered well to Walsh, who handed the sphere. The free kick helped the Lancs wall up. But overeagerness spoiled all attempts. The Irishmen now got agoing, Higginson indulging in some tricky work along with Walsh, and the pair of them made rings around the Lancs' defence. The Lancs now stole a march. Casey got a splendid chance to give his side the lead, but he shot yards wide. Still another chance was offered him to score, but he dallied on the ball and Ward robbed him and punted down field. The Lancs now made another effort to pierce Howlett's charge, but all to no purpose as Howlett saved in his usual style. The Inniskillings now took play in hand, Hutton and Kenny combining well. The latter centred well across the goal mouth. Higginson, who was lying handy, caught the sphere, and running through all opposition, he sent the ball into the left low corner of the net, making the score 2 to one in favour of the Inniskillings. on resuming the Lancs attacked in rare fashion, but Ward relieved and teh Inniskillings once more attacked, Walsh having hard lines is not scoring. Play now went in favour of the Inniskillings, whose play was really worth watching. Play was in Lancs' quarters when the referee's whistle sounded for full time, leaving the 108th again victorious by the following score:
Royal Inniskillings Fusiliers ... ... 2 goals
Lancashire Fusiliers... ... ... ... 1 goal

div.head: A BRITISH TERROR.
div.p: Our Treacherous Climate Prostrates the Weak Ones.
A Víctim' who collapsed through Loss of Strength, Back Pains
and Aggravated Indigestion, tolls of his completo cure by
Dr. Williams' Pink Pills.

"When I first settled down in England ti study your language and commerce," said Mr Louis Duchesne, "I was in the best of health, but after being here a few weeks I found that I was growing exceedingly weak, and this proved to be the beginniag of a long and serious illness."

The British climate is so treacherous and changeable that few are able to withstand its variations, and Mr. Duchesne's alarming experience should serve as a timely warning te all who feel the change of the season in their limbs, with sharp pains in the back, twinges of rhenatism, attacks of dizziness and weak ness, and a general disturbance of health.

Mr. Louis Duchesne, who is the son of a well known merchant in Paris, pursues his studies at La Rochelle, The Drive, Tonbridge, Kent, at which address a reporter of the Kent anl Sugsex Courier found him and obtained the following details :

"I am very fond of cricket," he stated, "and it was while at practice that I felt the first warnings that led to my breakdown of health I had sharp, cutting pains across my back, and I felt that all my strength had suddenly vanished. I bad to give up play because of the agony when I stooped and the alarming weak ness that overcame me.

"My back got worse and worse. When I arose in the morning I was quito unrefreshed by sleep; I felt, indeed, more tired than wher I went to bed, and it was hard work to dress, Throughout the day I was languid and tool no interest in anything. My head ached, my eyes were heavy, there was a most unpleasan taste in my mouth, and I began to notici a tightness across my chest. Besides, I was really very weak, felt cold and trembled con siderably. Then for days together I had no hunger, or, as you call it, no appetite. But around my heart I had much pain and a very uncomfortable feeling. The heavy dull pain in my head would not allow me to study; I felt dizzy when I moved about, and could not fix my thoughts on work. In fact, I was utterly wonn out.

"My weakness increased, and each day suffered torments after even the lightest of meals; I lost weight rapidly for want o nourishment So finally I went home to Paris and explained liny sufferings to my parents They took me to clever physicians, and I had much: medicine, but it was all in vain. In January I met a friend who remarked how ill looked and advised me to try Dr. Williams Pink Pills for Pale People. I was so impressed with all he told me about these pills that I began to take them. At the end of three weeks I knew that they had done a great deal for me. I felt quite different in health, and so much stronger that I could eat well and without any suffering after. I enjoyed meals, and soon Cagained all my lost weight and strength. Now I sleep well, my head is free from aches, my brain always clear, and feel scròng and active. I study without difficulty and can honestly say that I am perfectly well and that my cure was accomplished by Dr. Williams' Pink Pil!s."

When the Blood becomes thin and weak and the nerves lose "tone," 'the system rapidly breaks down. Dr. Williams' Pink Pill: fet Pale People casare good health by making Good Rich Blood in abundance and feeding the starved nerves. In both sexes they have cured Anæmia, General Weakness, Indigestion, Ec zema, Rheumatism, Sciatica, Neuralgia, St Vitus' Dance, Nervous Disorders, and Para lysis. Sold by all dealers, but see that you obtain the genuine pills, (seven words as above) for substitutes never cure and are useless. div.head: PROSPECTUS.
div.p: This Company has been formed for the purpose set out in its Memorandum of Association; to carry on business in Eypt and the Sudan, and more particularly to develop the well-known health resort of Helouan, near Cairo, by the acquisition of Land and Building sites, and by the erection of Buildings thereon, and generally with the object of acquiring interests of divers kinds in this rapidly improving district.

Although facilities for the acquisition of properties in Helogan will it is believed be afforded the Directors, yet no existing or proposed contracts to be entered into by the Co. on its inception are in force.

It is unnecessary to point out the paramount position held by Helouan as a health and pleasare resort, as the fame of its curative mineral springs and delightful climatic conditions are so well known and appreciated. But what is interesting to know, from a commercial point of view, is that the rapid growth of Helouan has attracted the attention of investors to the opportunities that now offer for the remunerative employment of capital in its development.

Helogan is situate about 16 miles from Cairo, and is connected by the Egyptian Delta. Light Railways, Limited, the directors of which are 80 alive to the future of this rising suburb of Cairo, that they have or are about to expend £60,000 in improving this branch of their lipn. The line to Tourah was recently doubled, thas accelerating the communication and enabling the Company, to put on a frequent service of Express Trains, (the journey oocupying about 30 minutes). The passenger service has already been equipped with luxurious modern corridor carriages fitted with Electric Light.

Helouan is becoming increasingly popular as a residential district for Cirt professional and business men, and a growing demand is apparent for more improved and commodious habitations than at present exist.

The yearly influx of visitors steadiliy paes, hotel and other residential establishments are feeling the tax on their resource to adaquately meet the requirements of those jug the health-giving adyantages of He desert air.
The Golf Links, Racecourse, Paddock, Racing Stables, etc., are important attractions, and the surroundings afford the most enjoyable place for horse exercice near Cairo.
The following is given in compliance wih the requirements of the Companies Act, 1900.

By a contract dated 17th November, 1906, and made between Andrew Percy Phillips on behalf of the Company and the Egyptian Lands and Agency, Limited, who are in consideration of paying all the costs, charges and expenses of and incident to the preparatoation, executing, stamping and registration of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company, and the preparation, advertising, printing and the circnlating of the prospectus, and all charges and legal expenses up to and including date of allotment, exclusive of stamps on Share Warrants, or any brokerage in respect of such capital, to receive a sum of seven thousand five hundred pounds from the Company.

The Egyptian Lands and Agency, Limited, has further undertaken to underwrite, for a commission of five per cent, payable by the Company, eighty five thousand Shares of £1 each. This contract will be adopted by the Company.
Various sub underwriting contracts exist:--
Two Directors, Mr. Elie Toriel and Mr. J. Robert Campbell are interested in the production of the Company to the extent of 500 s each in the Egyptian Lands and Agency ted.
The Directors are interested underwriters, and each will receive the five per cent. on the number of shares underwritten by him as follows:--
Elia Toriel, 5 000 shares. J. Ropart Campbel, 2.000 shares. Augaste Rossano, 3,000 share. Alfred Chamass, 3,000 shares, and Edward Forti 2,000 shares.

Applications for Shares should be made on the accompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company's Bankers. If no alloment is made, the application money will be returned in fall, and where the number of shares alloted is less than that applied for the surplus will be credited in reduction to the amount payable on allotment and any excess will be returned to the Applicant.
Failare to pay any instalment when due will render the previous payments liable to be forfeited.
A copy of the Memorandam of Association, which forms part of this Prospectus, is endorsed hereon.
The minimum snbscription upon which the Diretors may proceed to Allotment has been fixed by the Articles of Association et £100.000.

A brokerage of Sixpence per Share will be paid to Brokers and Bankers on all Shares applied for and allotted to the public on Application Forms hearing their stamps. No claims for brokerage will be recognised by tbe Company unless the Application Form is distinctly stamped with the name and address of Brokers whose clients are subscribing.

div.head: Egyptian Land and General Trust Limited.
div.p: DRAFT CIRCULAR.

Dear Sir (or Madam).--We are directed by the Board to inform you that since the date of the General Meeting they have disposed of lands in Cairo and Alexandria at prices which yielded substantial profits to the Company, Though recognising that all the money thus realised can be employed at the present time in extending the operations of the Company in Egypt, yet the Directors are of opinion that a part of the profite should be used in the distribution of a dividend to the sharebolders, and they have therefore resolved that an Interim Dividend of 1n. 6d. per sbare shall be paid to all Shareholdere, and shall become payable on the 15th of December 1906. Registered Shareholders in Egypt can receive the Dividend in respect of their holdings on presentation of their Certificates or Bearer Warrants, to the Office of the Company, 10 Sbaria Zervodachi, Cairo.

Where the registered holder desires that payment of the dividend shall be made to some person other than himself, he most obtain from the Company's Office, and fill up the form of Direction which has been prepared for that purpose. This form must be presented together with the Share Certificates by the person who 18 to receive payment of the dividend, and filed with the Company. Registered Shareholders residing in Borope will receive their Dividend Warrant in the ordinary course by post.
The transfer books of the Company in London will be closed from 4th December to 15th December 1906, both days inclusive.
We are directed by the Board to inform you that the Company have recently purchased a half share in some excellent land in Alexandria, and are extending their business in Egypt.
By Order'nf the Board,
MACK and PALMER.
Secretaries.
168 to 74, Palmerston House,
34, Old Broad Street,
London, E.C.

That the Articles of Association be altered in manner following : (a) The following articles shall be inserted after Article II, namely : 11 a. Upon any offer of shares to the public for subscription the Company may pay a commission of not more than 7% on the shares so offered to any person in consideration of his subscribing or agreeing to subscribe whether absolutely or conditionally for any shares in the Company or procuring or agreeing to procure subscriptions whether absolute or conditional for any shares in the Company.
11 b. Upon any offer of shares to the public for subscription the amount payable upon application on each share offered shall not be less than 5 per cent of the nominal amount of the share.

(b) In Article 42 b. the sentence beginning with the words "the holder" down to and including the words "of such warrant" shall be cancelled and in lieu thereof the following sentence shall be substituted "Unless otherwise " determined the following conditions shall "have effect as to share warrants."

(c). (d). The following clauses shall be inserted in Article 42 b, namely:

(xvii x). Fourteen days' notice at the least specifying the time and place fixed for any general meeting and in case of special business the general nature of such business shall be given to bearers of share warrants by adver. tisement in manner hereinafter provided.

(xvii b). Any notice required to be or which may be given to bearers of share warrants shall be sufficiently given if advertised once in The Times" and once in at least one newspaper published or circulating in Alexandrin.

(e). In Article 53 there shall be inserted after the words "shall be given" the following words, namely, "to members holding registered shares" and before the word "inember" in each place where that word occurs shall be added the word iguch."
(f). In Article 137 there shall be inserted after the word "Member" where that word first occurs the words "holding registered shares."
(8). In Article 140 there shall be inserted after the word "members" the words "holding registered shares."
(h). At the beginning of Article 141 there shall be inserted the following words, namely: -"Subject to the provisions of Article 12 h (xvii a)."

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
